You may or may not be aware that the Chinese Communist Party has been busy. Very busy. Over the past two years, an estimated 1 million Muslim Uighurs have been rounded up and placed in so-called "re-education camps." It's extremely difficult to report from the Uighur homeland of China's northwestern Xinjiang region. Journalists are followed wherever they go and prevented from visiting certain places or speaking with locals. So we posed as tourists and snuck in wearing hidden cameras. Twice. What we witnessed was an Orwellian state unlike any place on earth. In an exclusive VICE News investigation into a controversial Supreme Court decision and its impact on minority voters, we found how the gutting of the Voting Rights Act led to hundreds of closed polls. The 1965 bill, propelled by the historic march of protestors from Montgomery to Selma, Alabama, officially put an end to the literacy tests, poll taxes, and voting restrictions that had disenfranchised millions of minority voters for decades. And it went further than that: it also required areas of the country with a history of using these discriminatory tactics to get federal approval before making any changes to voting. üì∏ @atmccann

Greenland's glacial melt isn‚Äôt just the result of our planet‚Äôs warming air. Unlike most other bodies of water, the ocean surrounding Greenland gets warmer with increasing depth. That‚Äôs because warm, salty currents from the Atlantic are heavier than fresh glacial water, so those currents end up on the bottom. And that‚Äôs what‚Äôs got scientists‚Äô attention: our oceans absorb the heat trapped by greenhouse gases, so they‚Äôre getting warmer, and as they do, Greenland‚Äôs biggest, deepest glaciers are interacting with them ‚Äî and melting at increasing speeds. Link in bio for the full story. üì∏: @m.porcini

Catch F√©tiche ‚Äì loosely translated, ‚Äúvoodoo wrestling‚Äù ‚Äì is a uniquely Congolese fighting style: a combination of traditional African wrestling moves, old religious practices, and one man‚Äôs obsession with Hulk Hogan. No joke - Edingwe, generally recognized as the godfather of Catch F√©tiche, says that he saw Hulk Hogan on television, and was entranced.

Edingwe‚Äôs contribution was the use of f√©tiche, or voodoo - which he says was inspired by former President Mobutu, who in the 70s had put into place an official government policy of rejecting colonial influence and embracing what he considered ‚Äúauthentic‚Äù culture.

That policy eventually fell out of favor, but in the sport of Catch Fetiche, the voodoo stuck.

In modern Catch matches, pretty much anything goes: Hammers, concrete blocks, razors, fire, witchcraft. Live animals are common; as weapons, as ritual tools, or both. - @dexdigi

The car‚Äôs windshield bore an indentation the shape of a human head.

Moments earlier, the small sedan had struck a motorcycle that was carrying two Taliban fighters. Now, both men and the Kalashnikovs they‚Äôd been carrying were sprawled on the asphalt.

Nearby, young Talibs rallied to their motorcycles, two or three to a bike, and raced to their fellow fighters injured on the ground. From the opposite direction, two Afghan National Army pickups approached.

As the ANA soldiers came to a halt behind the sedan, they noticed the garb ‚Äî high-top sneakers, shalwar pants that exposed their ankles, rifle butts and radios protruding from the patus wrapped around their shoulders ‚Äî and quickly realized they‚Äôd driven into an encounter with the enemy.

On any other day, it would have been the cause for bloodshed. But it was Sunday, June 17, the third and final day of the historic ceasefire declared by the Afghan government and the Taliban leadership. Hit link in bio for more. (üì∑: @andrewquilty)

This stash house on the US/Mexico border is controlled by the Juarez Cartel. It's about 30 feet from the border fence that splits Juarez and El Paso, making it the perfect place for migrants looking to cross into the U.S. They come here - often brought by the cartel - for a place to sleep and some food, before taking their final steps into the U.S. About every 30 minutes a cargo train passes by on the U.S. side of the fence. And every so often it comes to an unpredictable stop. It's at this moment that the migrants at the house run to the backyard, grab a ladder to scale the fence and jump onto the stopped or slow-moving train. The train chugs along into El Paso, where the migrants hop off and hope to meet smugglers on the U.S. side, who will take them to safe houses in Texas and beyond. When @vicenews visited this stash house, we spoke to a migrant from Guatemala. She's traveling to the U.S. alone, hoping to reunite with her husband in Atlanta. She hasn't seen him for five years. She's waiting desperately for the right moment to cross into the U.S. And even though President Trump's ramped up border security and punishments against illegal immigrants, she tells us there's nothing he can say or do to stop her. See our report on #VICENewsTonight at 7:30 PM EDT on @HBO (üì∏ by @egrolled)

The ‚Äúmiracle clinic‚Äù is not easy to find. A few miles east of the Myanmar border, down an unmarked road surrounded by farmland outside the Thai town of Mae Sot, a cluster of tiny restaurants appears like an oasis, selling noodles, cold drinks, and snacks. Behind the shops, a gaggle of motorbike taxi drivers in bright orange vests rest in the shade waiting for their next fare. Nearly everyone passing by seems to have a young child, a baby, or one on the way.

It‚Äôs a calm scene, and it belies the vital role the Mae Tao Clinic has played for nearly three decades in the middle of the world‚Äôs longest-running civil war. Around 350 people arrive here every day seeking all kinds of care ‚Äî ophthalmology, surgery, acupuncture ‚Äî but maternal health is Mae Tao‚Äôs specialty. Since 1989, it‚Äôs helped tens of thousands of women through healthy pregnancies and births, serving generations of Burmese migrants and refugees in both Thailand and Myanmar with nowhere else to turn. Mae Tao provides access to trained staff, life-saving equipment, and resources like infant vaccinations and birth certificates for free. The record year for deliveries was 2012, when 3, 500 babies were born. Patients call it the ‚Äúmiracle clinic‚Äù because it seems too good to be true.

Click the link in bio to read more about the ‚Äúmiracle clinic‚Äù (üì∏ by @deciccaphoto)

The Shenandoah Valley Juvenile Center is tucked away on a dead-end road in rural Virginia, just off a highway named for a Confederate general. It has a beige-brick exterior and a green roof, and from the outside it doesn‚Äôt look especially intimidating. There‚Äôs no barbed wire or fencing around the perimeter, but inside it‚Äôs a juvenile jail housing several dozen boys and girls, including some as young as 10.

When J.Z., a 17-year-old immigrant from El Salvador, arrived there last summer, he didn‚Äôt know what to expect. The Immigration and Customs Enforcement officials escorting him hadn‚Äôt told him where they were taking him, or exactly why he was being detained. He‚Äôd been arrested for trespassing at his Long Island high school (a charge that was later dismissed) and spent about a month in a local jail before the federal agents came to pick him up and put him on a plane to Virginia.

He knew his situation had something to do with his immigration status, but he thought it was a misunderstanding and things would sort themselves out. Now he wasn‚Äôt so sure. ‚ÄúWhen I first saw that building, I was afraid,‚Äù he recalls. ‚ÄúI was like, what am I doing here? I‚Äôm not a criminal.‚Äù Inside, he was first ordered to shower, then questioned and assigned to the Delta wing of the jail, which is reserved for kids with good behavior ‚Äî Alpha was reserved for the troublemakers. But he still couldn‚Äôt get any answers. About a week passed before he was allowed to make a phone call to his mom. The staff would only tell him that he was ‚Äúun peligro para la comunidad‚Äù ‚Äî a danger to the community. It soon became clear they suspected he was involved with MS-13. ‚ÄúThey were always asking me, ‚ÄòWhen did you start with the gang? Do you have tattoos?‚Äô Everything,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúAlways trying to have any evidence contra ti.‚Äù Hit link in bio for more. (Photos by @cassandragiraldo)

From our correspondent Nigel Duara: 2/2

Incident Commander Who Doesn‚Äôt Want His Name Used For Fear if Retaliation: ‚ÄúThe only time the kids get scared is during Congressional tours. One Congressman made a little girl cry.‚Äù Here, he mimicked the unnamed Congressman‚Äôs approach, standing inches from a reporter‚Äôs face and repeated the questions from the Rep., ‚ÄúHow did you get here? Were you sexually assaulted?‚Äù He said he wanted to name the Congressman, but won‚Äôt. The Incident Commander says his company‚Äôs contract at Tornillo expires on July 13. Mark Weber, HHS spokesman, said that doesn‚Äôt mean the facility will close. They could find a new contractor to ‚Äústand up‚Äù tents again. He‚Äôs not sure what that process would be. There are categories of kids who aren‚Äôt here: pregnant girls or new mothers, kids younger than 13, those with significant mental health needs who are a danger to themselves or others. One kid was quarantined with strep throat. One was sent out for posing a danger to others. There are zero kids here with gang ties, says the Incident Commander. They look for tattoos or other indicators and haven‚Äôt found any. Call center: About 10 tables, a staff member seated at each, two kids across the desk. The kids get two 10-minute calls a week. A staffer dials and confirms the person on the other end of the line is family. The call recipient has to say the kid‚Äôs name before connecting. Tornillo itself is tiny, and cannot handle the safety needs here. So the contractor supplies full-time fire and EMS services. The facility is self-sufficient. Water trucked in, waste trucked out. 250 staff total operating 24/7. The whole encampment was set up in 4 days. It costs $700/day per child here. Weber of HHS says the standard is $250/day. Staff refs the soccer games, on three narrow fields that when taken together equal about the size of one whole soccer pitch. Asked a staffer if he hands out red cards. He laughed and said no. The loudest chants among the kids as we walked by were for Brazil and Mexico in the WC They haven‚Äôt had any ‚Äúrunners,‚Äù the Incident Commander said. If anyone tried to run, they would be chased by CBP and staff here, he said. (üì∏ by @egrolled)

From our correspondent Nigel Duara: 1/2

Observations from a tour of the Tornillo detention facility, where minors ages 13-17 are being held after their apprehension by DHS and initial sheltering by ICE: First, the Incident Commander, a private contractor who would only be identified by his first name, Kevin, says the private contractor staff operating the facility does not believe in separating children and ‚Äúhates this mission.‚Äù They are surrounded by a chain-link fence. We were not permitted to shoot video or take audio. I talked to one kid briefly, ‚Äúcomo estas?‚Äù He held my gaze for three seconds, laughed and said in Spanish, ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt be serious.‚Äù Fair enough. There are 400 beds and 326 kids. Hondurans: 117 El Salvador: 40 Guatemala: 162 The rest are Mexican, Nicaraguan and one Romanian. 14 are girls. 26 were separated from their parents, 3 have been reunified, so 23 separated kids left at the facility.There are showers for every 15 kids and toilets for every 10 kids. The kids are never alone except to shower or use the toilet. They are marched in single-file lines by staff in lime-green t-shirts from their sleeping tents to the dining hall or soccer fields. Dining hall: rows of white folding tables, 18 black folding chairs to a table, 16 on each end and one each at the head and foot. The tents are some kind of canvas material. Air conditioning runs constantly. There is a red metal-and-glass popcorn machine and a projection screen. They have ‚Äúage appropriate Spanish-language movies‚Äù but the kids just want to watch the World Cup. For breakfast today they had eggs, sausage links, ‚Äúsome potato thing,‚Äù said Kevin the Incident Commander, who added staff eats the same as the kids. 3 hot meals/day, 2 snacks. Sleeping tents: The tents are lined with black, metal bunk beds ‚Äî each have 20 beds, in two neat rows of ten. The floor and ceiling of each tent are made of white canvas-like material. The walls are lined  with reflective foil. I saw the game Sorry! and Uno cards. (üì∏ by @egrolled)

Black women know what to expect when they go to get their hair braided from a seasoned professional: a wall full of every possible shade of synthetic hair, TVs playing videos from countries across the African diaspora, pictures of famous braided celebrities like Alicia Keys and Ciara, a row of salon chairs, a cluster of mirrors, and combs and hair gels strewn all around. Anita Yeboah's hair braiding shop in Trenton, New Jersey, is no exception. But in many states those cultural clues aren‚Äôt enough to validate hairstylists in the eyes of local legislators and cosmetology boards. If you want to legally braid hair in Anita‚Äôs home state of New Jersey, you need to have up to $20,000 on hand and approximately 1,200 hours of free time for a class. That‚Äôs what it takes to get the state-mandated cosmetology license. Black and immigrant women who offer African hair braiding services say that‚Äôs not only a steep personal and financial investment but also an unjust occupational burden and an utter waste of their time. Beauty schools typically focus on practices like cutting, coloring, chemical straightening, and nail painting. Braiders rarely wash their clients‚Äô hair before they style, and they never use chemicals or sharp tools. The majority of them learn to braid at home in countries in Africa and the Caribbean, or in tight-knit communities in the United States. Hit link in bio to learn how hair braiders are fighting for their jobs.

One of President Donald Trump‚Äôs most controversial campaign promises was to enact a ‚Äútotal and complete shutdown‚Äù of Muslims entering the United States. Despite a slew of legal challenges, including a case that's being heard Wednesday by the Supreme Court, it‚Äôs clear that he‚Äôs delivering on his pledge, at least when it comes to keeping out Muslim refugees. The latest data from the State Department, which oversees the U.S. refugee program, shows that 1,891 Muslim refugees have been allowed to enter the country so far in the 2018 fiscal year. That‚Äôs a 90 percent drop from the same period last year, when the U.S. admitted 18,342 Muslim refugees. The numbers are especially dramatic when it comes to Syria, where more than 5 million people have fled horrific violence in a civil war that recently entered its eighth year. Just 44 Syrian refugees have been resettled in the U.S. in the first six months of the fiscal year ‚Äî compared to 5,839 over the same period last year. Of those 44 Syrians, only 27 identified themselves as Muslim. The trend coincides with an overall gutting of the U.S. refugee resettlement program by the Trump administration, resettlement experts say. The White House has near-total authority to limit the flow of refugees into the country, and the administration has set a cap of 45,000 for the current fiscal year. That ceiling was already going to be the lowest in recent history, but so far the U.S. is only on pace to admit 23,000 refugees, which would be the lowest total since the modern U.S. refugee program was established in 1980. Head to news.vice.com.

Aberham Hartsfield has been an oysterman in the Apalachicola Bay since the 1960s, but he can no longer afford to make a living from the Bay's dwindling oyster population. Apalachicola used to be home to a booming oyster fishing industry that is now shrinking due to a lack of fresh water making its way down the Apalachicola-Chattahoochee-Flint river system and into the Bay. One reason for the lack of fresh water is Georgia's agricultural system, which lifts 900 million gallons of fresh water from the river system each day. Oyster populations thrive in areas where salt and fresh water mix together, places like estuaries. Here, invasive conchs and urchin comprise a significant portion of Hartsfield's oyster catch from the Bay. See it on VICE News Tonight 7:30PM on @hbo. (üì∑: @carissahenderson)

North Korean officials have told their U.S. counterparts that Kim Jong Un is willing to discuss the denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula, according to a report Monday. However, experts warn the despot is not actually willing to relinquish his nuclear arsenal.

State Department officials have been talking to North Korea officials through its United Nations mission, the report said, while intelligence officers from both sides are using backchannels to communicate. Head to news.vice.com.

Discussions remain at a preliminary stage, but one of the key issues is the nuclear situation in the region. ‚ÄúThe U.S. has confirmed that Kim Jong Un is willing to discuss the denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula‚Äé,‚Äù a U.S. official confirmed. Yet despite the apparent progress, negotiations over what ‚Äúdenuclearization‚Äù actually means are likely to be fraught.

Researchers at the University of Alabama, Huntsville, in collaboration with Japanese scientists, received funding from NASA last week for their study called ‚ÄúMarsbees,‚Äù which would develop tiny, winged robots to colonize the Red Planet. These flying robots might navigate Mars‚Äô rocky terrain better than traditional rovers, which move slowly and often get stuck in the sand.

If the plan works out, the bees will deploy from a rover that will serve as their charging station and communications base. They‚Äôll gather data from the planet‚Äôs surface and might even work together, in small swarms, to gather rocks from the planet‚Äôs surface for analysis.

But the researchers still have some kinks to iron out. For one, Martian air is less dense than Earth‚Äôs. That could affect how the bees fly. Hit link in bio. üêù

The internet will soon be beamed down faster and wider from space, courtesy of Elon Musk.

It‚Äôs the first approval of a U.S.-licensed satellite constellation to provide broadband services using a new generation of low-Earth orbit satellite technologies. ‚ÄúWith this action, the Commission takes another step to increase high-speed broadband availability and competition in the United States,‚Äù the FCC said in a statement Thursday.

The U.S. Census Bureau plans to include a controversial question on the 2020 Census asking whether you‚Äôre a citizen. But after 17 years of war, the questionnaire still won‚Äôt address military history.

They still look beautiful, but coral reefs are dying at staggering rates ‚Äî experts project that 90 percent of the world's reefs will be gone by 2050. But a growing group of scientists around the world are searching for innovative solutions to make sure that doesn't happen.

Coral reefs are among the earth‚Äôs most precious natural resources. They harbor a million species and provide food for 500 million people around the world. But warming waters, pollution, and overfishing have badly damaged these precious ecosystems; roughly 50 percent of the world‚Äôs corals have been lost in just the last 30 years. ‚ÄúThe rates of change in our environment are far outpacing the intrinsic capacity of coral reefs to survive.‚Äù said Dr. Ruth Gates, the Director of the Hawaii Institute of Marine Biology, where she is pioneering research that could help corals survive. ‚ÄúIf we don‚Äôt mitigate at all, coral reefs will not be the things we‚Äôre worrying about, it will be the survival of our species.‚Äù Dr. Gates is just one of the scientists devising innovative ways to take coral reef restoration into their own hands. Her lab has started to breed and distribute, "super coral" ‚Äî the strongest breeds of coral that can thrive in warmer environments. Head to news.vice.com.

President Trump‚Äôs Cabinet chiefs have come under fire for their spending over the past year, from EPA head Scott Pruitt‚Äôs $43,000 soundproof booth, to Health and Human Services chief Tom Price‚Äôs estimated $900,000 in private and military jet travel (he has since left the administration). But more unusual is the role that the spouses of agency directors have played in both approving controversial expenses or benefitting from them.

Five Cabinet spouses are now connected to major and controversial expenditures of public funds, including Housing and Urban Development secretary Dr. Ben Carson‚Äôs $31,000 table, which he claims was chosen and ordered by his wife; a staff that was dedicated to CIA Director Mike Pompeo‚Äôs wife, and federal protection for Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke and his wife on their vacation to Turkey and Greece.

While it's not unusual for agency spouses to have visible, supportive roles at agencies, it is for them to get involved in operational decision-making, particularly since they aren't vetted or Senate-confirmed the way their spouses are. ‚ÄúThe level of involvement where you see Ben Carson and his wife picking out the table, that's very unusual,‚Äù said Jessica Tillipman, assistant dean at George Washington University and an expert on governmental ethics. Head to news.vice.com.

The brutal realities from the ground in Yemen often fail to make headlines, as the country is relegated to the shadows of more prominent Middle Eastern conflicts unfolding in Syria and Iraq. A lot of this has to do with access, or lack thereof.

After months of lobbying the Saudi-led coalition as well as various security officials, VICE News‚Äô @izyeung was finally granted permission to enter Yemen but as it turned out, getting there was the easy part.

Yemen more often than not feels totally cut off from the outside world. Public services are almost nonexistent; roads are in disrepair and phones often have no signal. Salaries haven‚Äôt been paid for months and those in positions of power are nowhere to be found. And with the total breakdown of the judicial system and thousands of forced abductions on both sides of the conflict, many of the people we met with in private were too afraid to go on the record.

VICE News was there to cover a range of stories, from the rise of terror to the breakdown of women's rights. But after only two weeks on the ground, we were forced to evacuate unexpectedly. An elevated security threat restricted our movements, making it impossible to complete our work.

Our experience is hardly unique; the risks of reporting from Yemen are high and the rewards can often feel minimal. The international community has the power to stop this war but has thus far kept to the sidelines. Just last week, U.S. senators voted down a resolution to halt American support for the Saudi-led bombing campaign. Head to news.vice.com.

Investigators are still trying to piece together what motivated Mark Anthony Conditt, a 23-year-old white male from an Austin suburb, to embark on his bombing spree, but one thing we do know: He was a remarkably skilled bomb maker.

Indeed, his devices were so brutally effective that profilers looking at the case suspected he‚Äôd had some sort of military or paramilitary training. In a 25-minute video confession recorded on his cell phone, Conditt described in detail how he built the six bombs with different detonation mechanisms, smokeless gunpowder, and batteries from Asia.

But according to Texas Gov. Greg Abbott, Conditt did not have a military background or training. He was homeschooled, apparently unemployed, and had previously worked in sales and as a computer technician. Family members have described him as a ‚Äúdeep thinker‚Äù and ‚Äúlow-key and peaceful.‚Äù None of that rules out some kind of paramilitary training, but it seems likely that Conditt acquired an impressive array of skills on his own, aided by the abundance of training materials and how-tos online, and that's concerning to law enforcement around the country. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt get to that record of reliability of devices exploding without a lot of practice,‚Äù said Scott Stewart, a former U.S. State Department special agent who now supervises terrorism and security issues for Stratfor, a global intelligence firm. It was 12:45 on a quiet summer night in 2015 when local councilman Michael Richter was jolted from his sleep by a huge bang. ‚ÄúAt first, I thought it was teenagers setting off fireworks in the backyard,‚Äù he recalled. Rushing to his kitchen window, he saw a huge plume of black smoke rising from his Volkswagen Polo parked outside. The car was destroyed and others nearby were damaged. Richter picked up the phone and called the police.

He didn‚Äôt know it yet, but the bombing was the first attack of a small group of local thugs and Nazi sympathizers known as the Freital Group. According to prosecutors, what started out as a loose association of far-right activists, football hooligans, and hate-filled anti-migrant Facebook groups soon spawned a terror organization. Its goal was clear: to drive out the few hundred refugees who‚Äôd recently settled in town, many of them fleeing conflict in Syria and Afghanistan, at any cost. Head to news.vice.com.

Last year, 171,000 migrants reached the shores of Europe ‚Äî down from more than a million at the height of crisis in 2015. The majority passed through Libya into Italy via the central Mediterranean route, a perilous crossing that took the lives of almost 3,000 people in 2017.
For many migrants, danger doesn‚Äôt end upon their safe arrival into Italy. Those looking to travel deeper into Europe through France now face Italian and French police, who are cracking down on well-known passages. As a result, many are forced to embark on another treacherous route this winter: a trek through the Alps. Head to news.vice.com. (Photo by @batedan)

One place where the #metoo movement‚Äôs impact has been seen is in calls to rape crisis hotlines. Silk Road creator Ross Ulbricht's fight for freedom has reached the end of the line. Currently serving a life sentence, the 33-year-old Texan has appealed to the Supreme Court, with his attorneys arguing the case involves unresolved constitutional questions about the scope of the Fourth Amendment in the digital age and the authority of federal judges to go above and beyond when handing down sentences. The Silk Road facilitated more than 1.5 million transactions before it was shut down, 95 percent of which involved sales of heroin, cocaine, meth, and other drugs. In addition to his life sentence, Ulbricht was at the time ordered to forfeit $184 million, the amount of money that allegedly passed through the website. Hit the link in bio for more. (Art: Elizabeth Williams via AP)

(4/4) In the 1950s, to comply with a law requiring educational facilities for native children, the federal government built a school at the center of what is now Newtok. But in doing so, the government changed the culture forever. Native Alaskans, who used to be seasonally nomadic, permanently settled by the coast. Today the school is still the center of village life in Newtok and the only building with running water, but the school is also threatened by erosion driven by climate change. If the school is lost and the new village is not ready, it is unclear what will happen to the people of Newtok. (üì∑: @jikaglez) #vicenewsphoto

(3/4) Della Carl holds her son WIlliam as she looks out to the eroding shoreline. Della is working on the construction of their new village. She is proud of building what she hopes will be her future home, and is determined to preserve culture and her way of life. (üì∑: @jikaglez) #vicenewsphoto

(2/4) Lucy Carl, one of Newtok's elders, worries that her children and grandchildren won't stay together if their village is not relocated in time. The village chose a piece of land nine miles away to move their entire village, but it is taking too long. (üì∑: @jikaglez) #vicenewsphoto

(1/4) For decades, Newtok,  a small village in Alaska has been disintegrating and falling into the surrounding river. And for more than two decades the people of Newtok have been trying to relocate the entire community. So far, the money they‚Äôve gathered falls far short of the estimated $130 million they‚Äôll ultimately need to make that happen. (üì∑: @jikaglez) #vicenewsphoto

In 2015, a Nigerian gang, the Black Axe, attempted to recruit and then murder a young migrant named Don Emeka (pictured).
The attack took place in the streets of Sicily's capital, Palermo, becoming a catalyst for Italian authorities to investigate the extent and breadth of the gang's reach in Sicily, as Italy's migrant crisis deepened. The trial of 24 gang members begins later this month. 
But, Sicily is also the home of the Mafia. And, as the police's investigation unfurled, it became clear that the Black Axe and the infamous Cosa Nostra crime syndicate have formed an unlikely working alliance, taking advantage of vulnerable migrants arriving, and developing sophisticated drug and trafficking networks across the island. Tune in tomorrow at 7:30 on @hbo. (Photo by @harrietdedman.) #vicenewsphoto

Inside an illegal reeducation camp for families with possible ties to ISIS
. . .
Designed specifically for people suspected of having links to ISIS fighters, this displaced persons camp in Bartella, Iraq, was home to 170 families who were forcibly relocated by Iraqi security forces during the fight for Mosul. According to a directive issued by Mosul‚Äôs district council, residents would ‚Äúreceive psychological and ideological rehabilitation,‚Äù after which they would be reintegrated into society.

But from its inception Bartella gave virtually no indication rehabilitation efforts were underway. Instead it appeared as an open-air prison camp for people whose only crime was their possible ties to ISIS, Human Right Watch‚Äôs Belkis Wille told VICE News. ‚ÄúThe way this was framed was that this was going to be some kind of rehabilitation camp, with some kind of rehabilitation program, and I have not seen anything to suggest, anywhere in Iraq, that such a program actually exists,‚Äù said Wille, senior Iraq researcher at HRW. ‚ÄúThe camp was theoretically there to provide rehabilitation, but in reality it was basically just going to be this awful prison camp with minimal services. ‚Äú Head to vicenews.com for more. (üì∑ by @samleesphoto) #vicenewsphoto

Twelve years ago, a criminal justice master‚Äôs student named Philip Stinson got into an argument with his grad school classmates about how often police officers committed crimes. His peers, many of whom were cops themselves, thought police crime was rare, but Stinson, himself a former cop and attorney, thought the problem was bigger than anyone knew. He bet a pint of ale that he could prove it.

This week, Stinson made good on his bet with an extensive police crime database offering the most comprehensive look ever at how often American cops are arrested, as well as some early insights into the consequences they face for breaking the laws they‚Äôre supposed to enforce. Hit the link in bio for a look inside the first database that tracks America's criminal cops. ‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è‚û°Ô∏è for more.

It seems like a paradox: Most doctors and scientists agree that the best way to treat opioid addiction is with other opioids. That‚Äôs because opioids are so powerful that they change the brain chemistry of the people who use them.
That‚Äôs why quitting opioids cold turkey rarely works, and why more and more people are looking to medication-assisted treatment for help.  Head to news.vice.com to watch how the best treatment for opioids might just be more opioids.

In two very similar towns at the center of the opioid crisis ‚Äî where drug overdose rates are more than twice the national average ‚Äî cops decided to do things differently this year. 
In Washington Court House, Ohio, a police chief fed up with unceasing overdose calls is treating addiction as a crime. Ninety miles south, on the other side of the Ohio River in Alexandria, Kentucky, law enforcement is for the first time approaching addiction as a disease. Their choices may be different, but both departments have the same goal: to get people using opioids including heroin and its deadlier cousins, fentanyl and carfentanil, into treatment and on the path to recovery. VICE News visited both towns to learn how these policies are working from the people living through them. Head to news.vice.com to read more of VICE News' latest issue A Nation in Recovery.

The caller delivered good news. Edna Schmeets had won a $19 million lottery jackpot. But she wasn't buying it, that is until somebody who claimed to be with the FBI called to assure her the prize was real.

Jamaicans specialize in the lottery scam. Here‚Äôs how it works: Fraudsters trick victims into paying taxes and fees they say are needed to claim a nonexistent jackpot. The scammers work in teams, using internet calling services to mimic familiar U.S. area codes, and they may pose as the IRS, the Nevada Gaming Commission, or the Federal Reserve, in addition to the FBI. The targets tend to be retirees over 80 who live alone.

It‚Äôs impossible to say exactly how much money is lost to the lottery scam. Official guesses have ranged from $120 million a year to as much as $1 billion, according to one estimate cited by the Justice Department. That means it could be nearly half as much Jamaica‚Äôs tourism industry, which is worth about $2 billion annually.

Hit to news.vice.com to read how one FBI agent in North Dakota took on the deadly scam that took over Jamaica. ‚û°Ô∏è for more on.

Across Equatoria, a region of South Sudan, villages are being swept up in violence as government and rebel forces vie for control, spelling destruction for once idyllic farming communities and signifying something deeper: Neither side is anywhere near securing a decisive military victory. South Sudan‚Äôs conflict was supposed to be over by now. At least that was the aim of a peace deal brokered by IGAD, an eight-country regional bloc, and backed by the U.S., the U.K., Norway, China, the U.N., and the EU. Signed in 2015, the pact sought to end the civil war by reinstating Riek Machar to his previous post as the young country‚Äôs first vice president, divvying up government positions between the signatories, and eventually reintegrating the rebels into the army. But the agreement was short-lived. We went behind the front lines with rebels in South Sudan, where the current war appears unwinnable. Head to news.vice.com for more.

‚û°Ô∏è for more photos. The recent carnage in Kabul is the latest sign that the already dire situation in the country can get even worse. Since the U.S. military handed security over to Afghan forces in December 2014, the government has rapidly lost territory to the Taliban, who now control or contest 40 percent of the country ‚Äî more land than they have had since being overthrown in 2001.

Nowhere is secure, no one is safe, and there is no end in sight.

Although craven attacks like the latest bombing generate grizzly headlines, the war in the countryside is considerably worse. Nowhere is the complete collapse of Afghanistan felt more than in provinces like Helmand (pictured), Paktia, Kandahar, Kunduz, and Khost, where the Taliban are able to not just launch spectacular attacks, but take and hold ground, often seizing large amounts of American-supplied military hardware in the process. #vicenewsphoto

Under a canopy hiding his laboratorio from patrolling military aircraft, Ricardo shreds green coca leaves until they carpet the jungle floor like confetti. It‚Äôs an initial step in a process that will turn the leaves into a light paste called pastabase, which Ricardo will sell to narcotraffickers after they arrive at his farm and name their price. In turn they will use boats, mules, and even submarines to surreptitiously move 55-gallon drums of pastabase to refineries on the outskirts of the nearby port city of Tumaco.

There, it will be processed into cocaine. ‚û°Ô∏è for pictures. To read more on how Colombia is fighting cocaine by making coca farmers choose ‚Äúpoverty or prison,‚Äù hit link in bio. #vicenewsphoto

Thirty minutes outside the city of Choman in the semiautonomous region of Iraqi Kurdistan, two Kurds climb out of a truck. They're armed with Kalashnikov rifles, but they‚Äôre not here to fight. They‚Äôre here to sell their cargo ‚Äî dozens of boxes filled with alcohol.

Slow TV is hugely popular in Norway. The concept is TV in real time, following a journey for its duration live or filming something that some might view as dull over a long period. VICE News Tonight went to the Arctic Circle for a behind-the-scenes look at the latest and most ambitious Slow TV project yet, a 7-day reindeer migration.

White Nose Syndrome was first documented affecting bats in a cave in New York in 2007. Since then, it's spread at an alarming rate across the country with new cases found as far as Minnesota. The invasive fungus can kill up to 98% of a cave's population and has already been responsible for over 5 million bat deaths in only a decade. VICE News correspondent Arielle Duhaime-Ross went to explore one affected area with researchers who are trying to stop its spread. 
Tune in to VICE News Tonight at 7:30.

After 52 years of pitched conflict between FARC guerrillas and the Colombian government that claimed the lives of some 220,000 people (the majority civilians), displaced 7 million more, and saw families torn apart by thousands of kidnappings, the country‚Äôs historic transition to peace has stumbled, but remains on course. As the peace deal is slowly implemented, around 6,300 former FARC guerrilla soldiers wait in 26 zonas veredales ‚Äî transitional camps ‚Äî across the country.

Original Mercury 7 astronaut Gordon Cooper was supposed to be looking for nuclear launch sites on his record-breaking Faith 9 flight in 1963. He did his duty over the course of those 22 revolutions around the earth, clicking away on a camera that kept getting loose in zero gravity, barely able to move for 34 hours. But he also kept getting anomalous readings from his equipment, pinging him for objects that were definitely not nuclear sites. The keen-eyed astronaut couldn‚Äôt help but put two and two together: metallic hulks beneath the sea, along the same routes used by Spanish traders? It had to be sunken treasure. Check out vicenews.com for the story on the astronaut who found treasure from space, and kept it a secret until his deathbed.

Every month since June 2009, Tad Steckler (picture 2) has received a disability benefits check from the Department of Veterans Affairs. Steckler retired from the Army at age 40 as a master sergeant with a Soldier‚Äôs Medal for heroism, and he‚Äôd built a new life on the foundation of his checks. The money covered rent on a three-bedroom home in Nebraska that he shared with his wife and her two daughters and the lease on the family‚Äôs Nissan Leaf electric car. It was all part of the agreement he‚Äôd made with the government when he enlisted out of high school: In exchange for his service, he‚Äôd be taken care of.
. . .
Last June, Steckler‚Äôs wife, Robyn Loveland, opened what she thought was just another envelope from the VA. Except this one wasn‚Äôt a check ‚Äî it was a bill (picture 3) for more than $10,000. A letter stated that Steckler had received thousands of dollars in disability compensation in error, and the VA was going to withhold future payment until the debt was paid.
. . .
A VICE News investigation has revealed that the VA sent nearly 187,000 of these overpayment notices last year. That represents just under 2 percent of those receiving benefits. Other cases we‚Äôve identified show overpayment claims similar in size to Steckler‚Äôs, with the potential to send veterans into crippling debt.
. . .

S√£o Paulo‚Äôs street art, injecting bursts of color into the thickets of concrete skyscrapers and revealing the city‚Äôs creative undercurrent, is famous across the globe and enjoys overwhelming support from Paulistas, but local lawmakers have historically taken a dimmer view. Enivo (real name Marcus Vin√≠cius, pictured), a well-known graffiti artist from the Graja√∫ neighborhood and a curator of the 23 de Maio project, compared the latest crackdown to the mythical ouroboros snake that eats itself: ‚ÄúThe last mayor was OK for graffiti, but before him S√£o Paulo had the same battles. The city was painted grey and the writers had to fight.‚Äù

Doria attempted to quell public outrage in late January when he proposed the creation of an open-air museum dedicated to the city‚Äôs graffiti. Shortly after taking office in January, S√£o Paulo‚Äôs new mayor, Jo√£o Doria, posed for photos in front of Avenida 23 de Maio, Latin America‚Äôs longest street mural. Then he turned a spray-gun on it and covered the vibrant art with drab grey.
. . .
Doria‚Äôs stunt might have kicked off his ‚ÄúOperation Beautiful City‚Äù ‚Äî an initiative he launched on Jan. 14 to revitalize the city‚Äôs urban landscape, in part, by painting over graffiti ‚Äî but it also reawakened a long-simmering feud between the city‚Äôs government and its graffiti artists.
. . .
Many Paulistas saw Doria‚Äôs targeting of the 5.3km public artwork on 23 de Maio, which was commissioned by his predecessor Fernando Haddad in 2015, as a bid to wipe out his rival‚Äôs cultural legacy and shatter the tentative truce he built with graffiti artists.

They were right.

Livestock herders are accustomed to lean times and cyclical drought. But elderly herders across Puntland, now taking shelter in camps for the internally displaced, say the current challenges are different.
. . .
‚ÄúI have seen many other droughts. This is the worst. Every few years we go through challenging times. But nothing like this, never,‚Äù livestock herder Adam Farrah says.
. . .
Over 6 million Somalis face the loss of their livestock-dependent livelihoods and risk acute malnutrition.
. . .
On the three-hour drive from Garowe to the Uusgure IDP camp, the main road is littered with the carcasses of goats and camels. Roadside water tanks dug into the ground are scorched and dry.
. . .
Local leaders say most herders have already lost 65 percent of their livestock. Families here depend on selling livestock for income, meat, and milk. Most say their livestock count has been reduced from hundreds to tens.
. . .
Read "On the edge: Somalia's new president inherits a country on the brink of disaster and famine" at news.vice.com. Photo by Adriane Ohanesian. #vicenewsphoto

Somalia is on the edge of famine, as severe drought threatens the entire country. Humanitarians say if nothing is done, it will be worse than the 2011 famine that killed a quarter-million people.
. . .
About 600 miles from Mogadishu, in Somalia‚Äôs Puntland region, every room in Garowe Hospital‚Äôs Stabilization Center is full of children under 5, most suffering from severe acute malnutrition.
. . .
Fadumo Adam (pictured) is 18 months old but the size of a newborn. Her parents brought her into the center five days ago, unconscious and barely alive. Now, she lies on her side, mouth open, and tries to cry. She stretches her arm out toward a water bottle on the bed.
. . .
Her father, 70-year-old Adam Farrah, says she is doing much better as he lifts her up to pour some water into her mouth. A nurse explained she‚Äôs too weak to even sit up on her own.
. . .
Photo by Adriane Ohanesian. To read more, head to news.vice.com. And tune in to VICE News Tonight weeknights on @HBO.

In mid-February, a group of international musicians got together in a small ski town in Norway to prepare for a concert. But instead of tuning their instruments and rehearsing in a warm, dry environment, they watched as sculptors shaped their instruments using chain saws and pickaxes in freezing cold weather. This was the start of Norway‚Äôs 12th annual Ice Music Festival‚Äî the world‚Äôs only gathering to celebrate the unpredictable melodies produced by instruments made out of ice.
. . .
The festival, which takes place in the town of Geilo, is the brainchild of Terje Isungset, a famous Norwegian percussionist. He came up with the idea for ‚ÄúIce Music‚Äù ‚Äî a genre he proudly says he invented ‚Äî while playing a concert under a frozen waterfall in 1999.
. . .
‚ÄúI decided to use elements of the waterfall,‚Äù he said while standing under an ice dome at the site of the festival. ‚ÄúSo, we tried a bit of ice at that concert, and it was a total hit; it was so incredibly beautiful.‚Äù
. . .
For more about Norway's Ice Music Festival, head to news.vice.com.

This was Laura Fantone‚Äôs vision: Her teenage foster daughter flies halfway around the world from a refugee camp in Ethiopia to San Jose, where she finds her new mom waiting with her long-lost friend and a crowd of supporters. They don‚Äôt share a language and barely know anything about each other, but they hug and cry joyful tears.

Two weeks earlier, it might‚Äôve gone down that way. But by the time the girl‚Äôs flight touched down in the Bay Area, Fantone (pictured right) was lucky her new daughter had made it into the country at all. On January 27, President Trump signed a sweeping executive order that suspended travel in the U.S. from seven predominantly Muslim countries and halted all refugee resettlement efforts for at least four months.

Fantone‚Äôs new 17-year-old daughter, an orphan from Eritrea, risked having her long-awaited journey to America slip away. But a federal judge opened a brief window when he issued a temporary restraining order, effectively halting Trump‚Äôs ban. Border agents are seizing travelers‚Äô phones and asking for their passwords.
. . .
Privacy advocates and lawyers are advising travelers to wipe their phones of all data when crossing the U.S. border following a number of new reports of border agents seizing mobile devices and demanding passwords.
. . .
This week, American customs agents seized the phone of a NASA employee and U.S. citizen and demanded his PIN. In November, Canadian photojournalist Ed Ou had his phone confiscated by border agents, who told him to unlock it, and questioned him for six hours when he refused. Two Moroccan Canadians were denied entry into the U.S. this month, but only after agents had rifled through their phones.
. . .
The issue could get worse, if a proposal from Homeland Security Secretary John Kelly to demand the social media passwords of some travelers becomes reality.
. . .
Growing uncertainty over the rules is putting the onus on people to protect themselves. Visit vicenews.com to learn more.

‚ÄúRoxanne Roxanne‚Äù premiered at Sundance last week, and sold for $3 million. ‚ÄúRoxanne‚Äôs Revenge‚Äù isn‚Äôt amazing just because it was a true freestyle ‚Äì there was no writing, and it was done in one take ‚Äì or that the punchlines still hold up today. It‚Äôs amazing, or sad, depending on how you look at it, because 27 years ago, a 15-year-old girl was able to encapsulate the conversation about sexism and public harassment we‚Äôre having today.

There‚Äôs plenty of punchlines and boasting, but most of the track is Roxanne telling dudes to leave her alone. Roxanne said that part of what inspired the song was that at 15, she was already getting harassed by men in the street.
. . .
‚ÄúThere is a very thin line between cat calls and disrespect,‚Äù she said, ‚Äúbecause if they gave you a cat call and you were timid or you didn‚Äôt respond, then they‚Äôd say something foul. ‚ÄòYou‚Äôre stuck up,‚Äô you know. It was almost their way of being able to back down without feeling like you like you punked them.‚Äù

Roxanne Shante was one of the best battle rappers in her era, male or female, period. But a lot of people didn‚Äôt want to recognize that.

When asked where his mother is, Mohamed insists she is ‚Äúat school.‚Äù Where? ‚ÄúUp there,‚Äù he says, pointing to the sky. Your sisters? ‚ÄúUp there,‚Äù he repeats. When asked whether his mom is in America, he scoots closer to the TV and turns it up.

How can Amina explain presidential policy to a 4-year-old? It‚Äôs simple: She doesn‚Äôt. After the call, Kaltumo, Mohamed‚Äôs caretaker in Kenya, says she understands Amina can no longer come for a visit. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs sad. I‚Äôm very sad,‚Äù she says, tearing up but still smiling. ‚ÄúShe won‚Äôt come. It will be hard. I‚Äôm a businesswoman. I was hoping to travel to Uganda and China [to buy clothes for my shop], but now I can‚Äôt leave here.‚Äù

Amina also feels helpless. She hasn‚Äôt slept since last Friday evening, when news of Trump‚Äôs order broke. ‚ÄúEvery day is getting worse,‚Äù she says.

Kaltumo, a 29-year-old single mother, has her hands full. She owns a clothing shop in Nairobi‚Äôs Eastleigh neighborhood, often called Little Mogadishu because of its predominantly Somali population. She rents a three-bedroom, eighth-floor apartment on one of the quieter streets, next to a large mosque and above a bookshop. Her ex-husband pays rent and school fees, but otherwise she supports her five sons with her earnings from the business.
. . .
In October, her old friend Layla came to her with another boy, 4 years old, the same as Kaltumo‚Äôs son Bilal. ‚ÄúHe didn‚Äôt have anyone else. Layla didn‚Äôt know anyone else,‚Äù Kaltumo says. ‚ÄúShe told me, ‚ÄòYou‚Äôre the only one.‚Äô I have kids. How can I just let Mohamed go? I couldn‚Äôt leave him.‚Äù
. . .
Kaltumo has never met Mohamed‚Äôs mother, Amina, but they speak weekly by phone, mostly about Mohamed and the progress of his paperwork. Amina sends Kaltumo money from the U.S. for transport to Mohamed‚Äôs appointments and on holidays, but little else.
. . .
Mohamed fits in well with her boys and Kaltumo brushes off questions about mothering a sixth son as if it‚Äôs nothing. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not angry with Amina,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúAs a mom, I understand. When we speak, she says, ‚ÄòMay God bless you.‚Äô I know it‚Äôs not a small thing [to take Mohamed in]. I always tell her, ‚ÄòIt‚Äôs OK. Today it‚Äôs you, tomorrow it‚Äôs me. You would do the same.‚Äô‚Äù
. . .
She admits that guiding him through the refugee registration process wears on her, but, she says, ‚ÄúThis child is still young and he needs me. I have volunteered to help, so we go back and forth, up and down, until he gets help.‚Äù
. . .
Read more of Mohamed‚Äôs story by clicking the link in our bio. Photo by @adrianeohanesian. #vicenewsphoto

Amina joined Columbus‚Äô population of nearly 40,000 Somalis, the second-largest community in the United States, in May 2015. She has a part-time job and a home for her family. Her eldest daughter, Faisa, is advancing through high school; her toddler, Mumtaz, is learning English faster than Somali. And Amina gave birth to a third baby girl, Mushtaq, last fall.
. . .
But now all she can think about is what her son Mohamed, now stranded in Nairobi, Kenya, said to her when she left. ‚ÄúIf you leave me, I won‚Äôt be able to call you Mom again.‚Äù On Tuesday morning, four days after Trump signed his executive order barring entry for Somalis to the U.S., she sits in the dark, deciding whether and how to tell Mohamed what the news in America means for their future together. She checks how much money is left on her international call account: $7.45. She doesn‚Äôt know if she can handle telling him, if she can handle hearing herself tell him.
. . .
Read more of Amina and Mohamed‚Äôs story by clicking the link in our bio. Photo by @maddiemcgarvey. #vicenewsphoto

‚ÄúWhy do you hate me, Mommy?‚Äù Mohamed asks his mother almost every time they speak. ‚ÄúWhy haven‚Äôt you come for me?‚Äù
. . .
These phone calls, just a few minutes each, are the only time Amina, who lives in Ohio, sees her son. Mohamed is living in Nairobi, Kenya, with a friend ‚Äî a stranger, really, who was kind enough to take him in. He turned 4 in October. The family hoped he would soon join Amina, her husband, and her three daughters in the U.S. They are on top of the paperwork and Mohamed is a just few steps short of the necessary approvals in his nearly two-year-long reunification process.
. . .
In recent months, frustrated by the waiting, Amina had devised a plan: She‚Äôd fly to Kenya and bring Mohamed back with her. She knew his application was close and she didn‚Äôt want to take any chances on the last legs of his process. Against her caseworker‚Äôs advice, she paid the $325 fee and applied for a refugee traveler‚Äôs visa for herself and her daughter Mumtaz. Mohamed had spent too much time without his mother, and she was worried she was losing him, that her phone calls were failing to convince him he was loved.
. . .
Her plan is off the rails now. On Monday, she received a letter from the State Department telling her she was one step closer to earning her travel visa, one step closer to reuniting with Mohamed in Kenya. But two days before that, President Trump had signed an executive order freezing all refugee resettlement efforts and barring travelers from seven countries, including Somalia, from entering the U.S. It‚Äôs a double blow: Mohamed‚Äôs reunification application is likely to suffer serious delays along with everyone else‚Äôs, and Amina can‚Äôt even go to see him as long as the visa restrictions remain in place. Their temporary separation is starting to feel permanent.
. . .
Read more of Amina and Mohamed‚Äôs story by clicking the link in our bio. Photo by @adrianeohanesian. #vicenewsphoto

As UK's House of Commons debates the legislation that begins the country's exit from the EU, fishermen are one of the most vocal groups of Brexit-teers. The fisheries minister says British fishermen will be able to catch hundreds of thousands of tons more fish after Brexit because it will be able to overhaul "unfair" fishing quotas. Many British fishermen claim that the fishing limits set by the EU‚Äôs central Fishing Policy is unfair and has affected their livelihood. Though with 66% percent of British fish being exported, fishermen will still need to access the EU market in any brokered EU-deal.

@carnegiemellon has deployed an AI bot to play humans in No Limit Hold‚Äôem. Over 20 days, the bot will face four pros, playing shares of the $200,000 prize purse. The AI has the edge, and if successful could open up the door to key decision making moves that could help fight disease and cyber threats.
. . .
Advances in artificial intelligence research have been progressing  at a pace even those in the industry have been surprised by in recent years, but beating heads-up no-limit Texas Hold‚Äôem will stand as achievement above the rest because of its real world implications.
. . .
‚ÄúI would say from an AI perspective, [beating Go and poker] are both great achievements, but from a practical perspective, this is much more important in that very few real world situations are perfect information games, while most real world situations are imperfect information games,‚Äù Tuomas Sandholm said.
. . .
It means that the algorithm could have much greater implications for solving problems in the real world. Sandholm, who developed the algorithm with graduate student Noam Brown at Carnegie Mellon University, believes that Libratus could be applied to a wide range of industries, including cybersecurity, the military, negotiations and medical diagnoses.
. . .
‚ÄúThese are not algorithms for solving poker, they are algorithms for solving imperfect information games in general and poker is just a benchmark through which the different research groups around the world compare performance against each other and build up on each other‚Äôs algorithmic techniques,‚Äù Sandholm said.
. . .
Read more on vicenews.com. And tune in to VICE News Tonight weeknights at 7:30 on @HBO.

Since 2015, when the migration crisis began to hit, camps like this have sprung up across the continent from Greece to France, crowded with desperate migrants enduring wretched conditions in their quest to reach a better life in Europe.

This latest miserable shantytown, containing as many as 2,000 migrants, is made up of a cluster of abandoned railway warehouses in central Belgrade,Serbia, where hundreds of men and children sleep rough behind the city‚Äôs bus depot.

Following failed attempts to cross the borders into the European Union, the migrants are stuck here in hellish conditions. Their desperate situation has prompted warnings from the United Nations that some could die during a brutally cold winter snap.

In 1955, there were 560,000 patients who lived full-time in state psychiatric facilities. Today there are just 45,000. Yes California‚Äôs founder Louis Marinelli and Anti-Globalist Movement president Alexander Ionov answer questions during Yes California‚Äôs ‚Äúembassy‚Äù opening in Moscow, Russia on Dec. 18. Photo by Alec Luhn.
. . .
The first outpost of California's slapdash secessionist movement, Yes California, has opened. Housed in a research institute in northwestern Moscow, the offices are described as an "embassy" by its 30-year-old founder Louis Marinelli. Photographs of Fidel Castro, Che Guevara, Hugo Chavez, and Bashar Assad hang on one wall. A portrait of Vladimir Putin occupies a place of honor between a Christmas tree and a Russian flag on another. A blue banner reads, "Welcome to the Embassy of the Independent Republic of California, Moscow, Russia."
. . .
Marinelli denies receiving support from the Kremlin, but the opening of his group's "embassy" raises broader questions concerning Russia's growing and diffuse influence on the politics of Western countries. "From the Kremlin's perspective, supporting these kind of networking opportunities, whether for fringe political parties across Europe or secessionist movements across Europe and the United States, is to support opposition in countries that the Kremlin sees as competitors," said Alina Polyakova, a senior fellow at the Washington, D.C.-based Atlantic Council think tank. "It's to destabilize Western states." Read more on vicenews.com.

Tylyia Moore, 7, stands outside the doors of the now shuttered Oakman Elementary. Graffiti on the building reads "Lies Closed This School." Photo by @cassandragiraldo.
. . .
The gutting of Detroit's public schools is the result of an experiment started 23 years ago, when education reformers including Betsy DeVos, now Donald Trump's pick to lead the Education Department, got Michigan to bet big on charters and school choice. DeVos has made clear her goal is to use charters to eventually get public dollars to private and religious schools, but the consequences of her school choice policy in Detroit leave gaping questions about how she will care for America's public schools.
. . .
In Detroit, choice has come largely at the expense of traditional public school districts and schools like Oakman. As students joined new charters, public school enrollment and funding fell. Unregulated competition pushed these schools into near-unrecoverable insolvency and allowed dubious for-profit charter operators to prosper without establishing a track record of better outcomes for students. The premise of school choice is that competition raises all sectors, but in Detroit, and many other cities around the country, that just hasn't happened. "What competition ends up producing is not a choice of failing vs. good schools but a bunch of similarly mediocre schools," said Thomas Pedroni, associate professor at Wayne State University's School of Education. Read "Out of Options" at vicenews.com. #vicenewsphoto

This boat was propped up on wooden chocks when VICE News found it, the deep cracks lining its 65-foot hull suggested that its seagoing days should have long been over. And for a while they were, decommissioned after more than 40 years ferrying tourists along the region's scenic coastline.

But a smuggler acquired then refloated it, and on a dark mid-September night in 2015, ushered aboard more than 270 mostly Syrian asylum seekers ‚Äî including children, pregnant women, the sick, and elderly ‚Äî desperate to cross from Turkey to the Greek island of Kos and on to mainland Europe. The youngest passenger was born just a few days before setting off, the oldest well over 70. 
At least 22 of them never made it off again ‚Äî drowned as the boat took on water in the Aegean Sea after being intercepted by the Turkish coast guard.
